Literature Review: The ubiquitin-proteasome system (UPS) plays a crucial role in plant immunity and has emerged as a prime target for manipulation by microbial pathogens. This literature review explores the intricate relationship between the plant UPS, immune responses, and pathogen effectors, highlighting the mechanisms by which pathogens subvert host defenses through UPS interference. The UPS is a highly conserved protein degradation pathway in eukaryotes, responsible for maintaining cellular proteostasis and regulating various biological processes. In plants, the UPS has been shown to be integral to all stages of immunity, from pathogen perception to defense execution. Marino et al. (2012) provided a comprehensive overview of how the UPS regulates plant immune responses, emphasizing its role in hormone signaling, transcriptional reprogramming, and cell death regulation. The perception of pathogens by plants initiates a complex cascade of immune responses. Pattern recognition receptors (PRRs) detect conserved microbial features, triggering pattern-triggered immunity (PTI). Interestingly, the UPS has been implicated in the regulation of PRR abundance and activity. For instance, Lu et al. (2011) demonstrated that the E3 ubiquitin ligase PUB13 negatively regulates the flagellin receptor FLS2 through ubiquitination and subsequent degradation, fine-tuning immune responses. Effector-triggered immunity (ETI), a more robust immune response activated upon recognition of pathogen effectors by plant resistance (R) proteins, is also tightly regulated by the UPS. Cheng et al. (2011) revealed that the stability of the R protein RPM1 is controlled by the E3 ligase complex SCF(CPR1), highlighting the importance of UPS-mediated protein turnover in ETI regulation. Given the central role of the UPS in plant immunity, it is not surprising that pathogens have evolved sophisticated mechanisms to manipulate this system. Banfield (2015) provided an extensive review of how bacterial, fungal, and oomycete pathogens target the host UPS to promote virulence. One common strategy employed by pathogens is the secretion of effector proteins that mimic or modify UPS components. A striking example of UPS manipulation by pathogens is the Pseudomonas syringae effector AvrPtoB, which functions as an E3 ubiquitin ligase. Abramovitch et al. (2006) demonstrated that AvrPtoB targets the tomato protein kinase Fen for degradation, suppressing host cell death and promoting bacterial virulence. This finding underscores how pathogens can hijack the host UPS machinery to their advantage. Oomycete pathogens, such as Phytophthora infestans, also employ effectors that interfere with the host UPS. Bos et al. (2010) characterized the RXLR effector AVR3a, which stabilizes the host E3 ligase CMPG1, preventing its normal function in immunity-associated cell death. This example illustrates how pathogens can manipulate the UPS by altering the stability of specific host proteins. The manipulation of the UPS by pathogens is not limited to protein degradation. Some effectors interfere with ubiquitination processes without targeting proteins for degradation. For instance, Üstün et al. (2014) showed that the Xanthomonas campestris effector XopJ inhibits proteasome activity and interferes with salicylic acid-mediated defense responses, demonstrating how pathogens can disrupt UPS function at multiple levels. Recent advances in proteomics and structural biology have provided deeper insights into the molecular mechanisms of UPS manipulation by pathogens. Pruneda et al. (2016) used structural approaches to elucidate how bacterial effectors mimic eukaryotic E3 ligases, revealing convergent evolution in UPS manipulation strategies across diverse pathogens. The intricate interplay between the plant UPS and pathogen effectors has important implications for developing novel strategies to enhance crop resistance. Duplan and Rivas (2014) discussed the potential of engineering the plant UPS to improve disease resistance, highlighting the need for a deeper understanding of UPS-mediated immunity regulation. In conclusion, the plant UPS emerges as a critical regulator of immunity and a prime target for manipulation by microbial pathogens. The diverse mechanisms by which pathogens interfere with the UPS underscore the evolutionary arms race between plants and their microbial invaders. Future research in this field will likely uncover new aspects of UPS regulation in plant immunity and reveal novel pathogen manipulation strategies, potentially leading to innovative approaches for crop protection.
